qas.question: What is a good indicator of the rate of infectious diarrhea?
Why does living in poverty raise your risk of diarrhea?

answers.text: from the conditions under which impoverished people live

qas.question: What causes this to be exacerbated?

answers.text: the lack of adequate, available, and affordable medical care.

qas.question: What indicates the rate of medical care?

plausible_answers.text: from the conditions under which impoverished people live

qas.question: Why does poverty raise your risk of nutrient losses?
What prevents poor people from defending against human pathogens?

plausible_answers.text: poor housing, crowding, dirt floors, lack of access to clean water or to sanitary disposal of fecal waste (sanitation)

qas.question: What are some examples that the lack of affordable medical care is associated with?
What restricts the ability to provide sanitation?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Poverty<b3_0/><a0_0/> is a good indicator of the rate of infectious diarrhea in a population. This association does not stem from poverty itself, but rather <a1_0><b4_0>from the conditions under which impoverished people live<b4_0/><a1_0/>. <b5_0>The absence of certain resources<b5_0/> compromises the ability of the poor to defend themselves against infectious diarrhea. "Poverty is associated with <b6_0>poor housing, crowding, dirt floors, lack of access to clean water or to sanitary disposal of fecal waste (sanitation)<b6_0/>, cohabitation with domestic animals that may carry human pathogens, and a lack of refrigerated storage for food, all of which increase the frequency of diarrhea... <b7_0>Poverty<b7_0/> also restricts the ability to provide age-appropriate, nutritionally balanced diets or to modify diets when diarrhea develops so as to mitigate and repair nutrient losses. The impact is exacerbated by <a2_0>the lack of adequate, available, and affordable medical care.<a2_0/>"
